thread.title: Hikers - lacking water, food, lights - rescued from Mount Washington
thread.title_full: Hikers - lacking water, food, lights - rescued from Mount Washington | Boston Herald

author: Laurel J. Sweet
title: Hikers - lacking water, food, lights - rescued from Mount Washington
text:
Two leaf-peepers from Lowell who couldn't get seats on the sold-out Cog Railway had to be rescued from Mount Washington early this morning after one of them twisted his ankle trying to hike his way down to the parking lot, according to New Hampshire Fish and Game officials.
Department Lt. Wayne T. Saunders said Tong Wu, 26, and Haofan Gao, 25, climbed to the peak yesterday with the intent of riding the train back down. However, Saunders said, there were no seats available, so the friends set out on foot.
At 6:45 p.m., Saunders said the Appalachian Mountain Club received a call that the pair were on the Ammonoosuc Ravine Trail, but Wu had twisted his ankle and couldn't walk.
"Compounding the problem was that they were not prepared," Saunders said. "They lacked food and water, proper clothing and lights."
Two conservation officers stationed at the top of Mount Washington reached Wu and Gao at midnight and helped them back up the mountain - a process that took until 3:30 a.m.
Wu and Gao were then taken by vehicle down the auto road to their vehicle.
-laurel.sweet@bostonherald.com
